comments.author: GutentagCharlie

comments.text:
WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU WAITING FOR, AMERIKA?

MAKE THIS MAN YOUR PRESIDENT AS SOON AS HE HAS TO STAND DOWN FROM URUGUAY!!

he's like a Jesse Ventura without the 'body' and the ex-military stuff!

a genuinely meek and humble man. an incorruptible human being!
let the fucking corporations offer him $4,000,000,000 and record him 
laughing at them.

this guy would never be voted out of office!!
10 years in solitary. the most i've ever done is 8 weeks [tho i was a lot 
younger then] and i refused to eat for the first 3 weeks. i drank only 
water.

Pepe Mujica? you remind me so much of the only man i ever truly 
respected... my grandfather. a man who always had a smile for everyone, who 
played football with me and my brother when he was 78 and we were just 8 or 
9. he gave us his last pennies. a simple, humble, friendly and happy old 
man who loved playing with his grandkids.

 he never grew bored of us, he read socialist and communist literature in a 
socialist UK. 
a welsh farm boy who was forced to leave home after his dad [my great 
grandfather] died and his mother almost died of the same disease... until 
the authorities took the farm away because he, at 12, was considered unfit 
to take care of the farm and should be in school even tho his bedridden 
mother  [my great grandmother] 'home taught' him and his younger brother.

from the age of 10 him and his brother had taken care of the farm but 
english landowners 'stole' their farm and forced them to live in a 2 
bedroomed flat 80 miles away in an urban environment, which was a world 
they had never experienced before. their farm was sold wo their consent and 
they were forced to accept 'peanuts' because they were simple poor farm 
people who knew nothig of the corruption of capitalism.

Long Live Pepe Mujica!﻿

comments.text:
thats all politics is when you really look at it. there has never been a 
political solution to any problem. 
a persons mind is only as good as the language he/ she speaks because we 
think in language. there is no truth but it is factual that they who we 
believe controls individual nations is not man but a machine that has been 
made by man. so therefore it is still subject to evolution. the very idea 
of an established system comes from fixed notions of an ideal society. 
there are no fixed notions, beauty is all in the mind of the individual, an 
alien from another galaxy that has gills is beautiful in his own context.
 so while we sit here and debate what we think is beautiful ideas we should 
really put forth our all to investigate everything. give all our heart to 
question all things. 
 if you take all the money out of the music industry you will have better 
artists because it is the ones who have a real cause, a real fire in their 
heart are the real artists.

comments.author: manuel pichardo

comments.text:
You just have to realize here in the US our news shows are almost all owned 
by large corporations and the large corporations are the ones that have 
bought and paid for our government. Trust me those of us that live here and 
pay attention to how things work are not happy about it. The average people 
of the country never get what we want. Our voting system dosnt work the way 
it should. Our military endlessly does stuff we dont want it doing. Its 
been used to make rich government contractors even richer and control the 
oil of the world for a long time.  Most americans are just like people in 
the rest of the world. We just want to live a normal peaceful life with 
lower taxes more freedom and less crime.  But everything in our government 
revolves around who pays our government leaders the most money. So oil 
companies tend to control the government and other large companies also get 
their say in while the average person is ignored.

comments.text:
Mujica did not fight a dictatorship but he didn't fight a real democracy. 
He was against an elected government who closed newspapers and marginalized 
opposition, just like chavez did and maduro does.﻿
comments.author: Juan Pablo Fernández

comments.text:
El problema con los libros en general es que no vivo en Uruguay, los 
periodicos online no tienen todavía registros tan antiguos y una 
enciclopedia obviamente no tiene artículos de periodico enteros o 
discusiones medianamente detalladas al respecto como para juzgar la 
veracidad de las afirmaciones

Pero si, hay muchos tonos de gris ahí: si bien Pacheco no era un dictador 
Mujica tampoco era un delincuente común.

un saludo cordial
comments.author: Juan Pablo Fernández

comments.text:
+Juan Pablo Fernández Es muy sencillo, en cualquier libro de historia mas o 
menos respetable están los hechos, lo mismo que en las enciclopedias, o si 
le gustan mas las fuentes primarias, se puede dar una vuelta por la 
biblioteca nacional y leer los diarios de la época. En realidad, los hechos 
los sabemos todos. Que Mujica fue guerrillero todos lo saben, hasta estos 
yankees. Lo unico que es una falacia es lo de que la dictadura se veia 
venir con Pacheco, o que directamente Pacheco era dictador. Pacheco, 
indudablemente, tuvo que meter mano dura para combatir a los tupamaros y a 
sus secuaces, pero lejos estaba de ser un dictador. Ahora, todo el 
descalabro social y politico que generó la guerrilla y la agitacón 
comunista, sumado a las tensiones inehrentes de la epoca debido a la guerra 
fría, obviamente que precipitaron el golpe de estado Buena suerte!
comments.author: Javier Añón

comments.text:
Nadie que no de un golpe militar puede ser culpable del golpe. Pero las 
demás cosas que dices vale la pena investigarlas y estaría de acuerdo con 
usted.
Sabe Javier donde puedo encontrar algo al respecto?
Gracias de antemano
comments.author: Juan Pablo Fernández

comments.text:
You should ask why the goverment had to close those newspapers in the first 
place. There were left wing newspapers advocating an armed revolution. That 
makes Mujica and his fellows indirectly responsible for the later military 
dictatorship.
comments.author: Javier Añón

comments.text:
Mujica did not fight a dictatorship but he didn't fight a real democracy. 
He was against an elected government who closed newspapers and marginalized 
opposition, just like chavez did and maduro does.﻿
comments.author: Juan Pablo Fernández

comments.text:
I'm uruguayan, and although I feel flattered about all the positive 
comments about my country , I have to say many of your ideas about Mujica 
are simply wrong. Mujica did not fight against a dictatorship. His group 
,called Tupamaros, was formed many years before the military  coup. They 
fought against a democratically elected government, because they wanted to 
make a Socialist revolution, following the example of Castro in Cuba. He 
and his group robbed, tortured and killed many innocent people.


Furthermore, in the late 90's, he tried to prevent a group of basque 
terrorists belonging to ETA, who were living in Uruguay, from being taken 
to Spain to be judged for their crimes.  

The man is not a hero. He's humble, yes. He's not materialistic, yes. But 
he's not a hero.﻿
